coredata.dc:title: Fine structure above the carbon K-edge in methane and in the fluoromethanes
coredata.dc:creator: Brown, Frederick C.
Bachrach, R.Z.
Bianconi, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Synchroton radiation has been utilized to obtain high resolution soft X-ray absorption spectra above the carbon K-edges in CH4, CD4 and the fluoromethanes. The results near threshold are in close agreement with forward scattering electron energy loss data in the cases where that comparison can be made. With increasing fluorination the Rydberg-like threshold spectra of methane shift to higher energy and evolve into a complex band in CF4. Well above threshold extended fine structure (EXAFS) is observed in CF4.

Absorption spectroscopy above the carbon K-edge at photon energies of about 284 eV (43.7 A) has long been of interest as a possible technique for obtaining structural and energy level information. For example, extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) [1 ] if extended into this relatively long wavelength X-ray region might be informative about changes in interatomic distances in organic molecules. It is also true that the detailed absorption structure observed within a few electron volts of a deep level threshold is specific to the atomic environment whether that environment is for an atom in the condensed state or a molecular gas. In the case of light elements and sufficiently small molecules it should be possible to compare observations of threshold structure with ab initio theory of excitation from core levels to excited Rydberg and valence * Supported in part by the National Science Foundation under grant no. This would relate to recent ideas about inner and outer-well effective potentials (2] and could yield a better understanding of threshold response in more corr plicated systems. We have studied methane and the series of fluoromethanes to explore these ideas. Unfortunately the K-edges of carbon (284 eV), nitrogen (399 eV) and oxygen (532 eV) lie in an extremely awkward part of the electromagnetic spectrum. The source problem has been solved to some extent with the advent of synchrotron radiation, however, monochromators in this grazing incidence region of the vacuum ultraviolet suffer from low efficiency and everpresent carbon contamination. The latter can be minimized by the use of fresh surfaces in ultrahigh vacuum. The present measurements were made with the ultrahigh vacuum "grasshopper" monochromator (3] on the four degree line at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Project. The various gases studied were contained at pressures up to 3 torr within a thin Window 425 Volume 54, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 March 1978 gas cell 13_5 cm long inside a separate ultrahigh vacuum chamber beyond the focussing mirror after the exit slit of the monochromator. Evaporated titanium films 1000 A thick were supported by 82% transparent Ni mesh over six mm diameter apertures in two miniconflat flanges. It was possible to make these windows sufficiently free of holes so that a pressure of 10-9 torr could be maintained outside the cell with several torr of gas inside- A photon pass band from 50 eV up to the Ledge of Ti at 460 eV was achieved using a 2400 21mm replica grating of 2 m radius in the monochromator. With entrance and exit slits set at approximately 15 micron a spectral bandpass of about 0.4 eV at 284 eV was achieved. The instrument was calibrated with reference to the 2P3/, ->4s transition of argon gas shown by Nakamura et al. [4] to occur at 244 ± 0.05 eV. Additional low level structure can be seen in the spectrum for CF4 beyond 308 eV. This is shown in fig. 2 with data extending 150 V above threshold.
